He was set at liberty, and is now on his way home to Washington, where the Union citizens are preparing to give him an ovation.
This committee was also instructed to, and did, deliver an order to the Virginia chivalry that North Carolina was capable of managing her own affairs, and that no more of her citizens must be taken out of the State.

In connection with this matter, we also learn that J. Davis, a few days since, ordered Gov. Clark to furnish them with all the meant of transportation and defence possible, to aid him in the passage to and through the cotton States, and also for additional troops.
Gov. Clark, backed by the Convention, informed him that he had received all the aid from North Carolina that he could expect, and that hereafter no more troops would be permitted to leave the State, and has ordered all the North Carolina State troops home.
Gov. Clark informed the rebels that they could use the railroads in retreating home wards, and that they would run their own risk of being intercepted by a Union force at any part of the State.
The above information comes from a member of the Convention.

div4.p: On the 80th ultimo, at St. Paul's Church Lynchburg, by the Rev. Wm. H. Kinokle, Captain J. A. Sitgreaves, C. S. A., and Eliza Beverly, only daughter of Commodore John Rudd, C. S. N.
In this city, on the 7th inst, by Rev. T. V. Moore, D. D., Dr. Charles Henry Cole, C. S. A., and Miss Susan Ellen Grubbs, daughter of Anderson and Susan Grubbs.
At the residence of Wm. Brent, on 5th st. Dr. H. T. Bodder.
His friends, and those of Mr. Brent, are invited to attend his funeral, from Mr. Brent residence, at 11 o'clock to-day.
On Thursday morning, 22d inst., Lucy A. Mosby, aged 11 years 5 months and 4 days.

lg.l: Dearest Lucy, thou hast left us,
We thy loss most deeply feel,
But 'tis God that hast bereft us,
He can all our sorrows heal.

div4.p: The funeral will take place at her father's residence, on 17th street, at 8 o'clock A. M. The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend without further notices.
On Wednesday evening, 21st inst., in the ninth year of his age, at the residence of his father, Il Henrico county, Charlie Warren, son of William and Mary W. Folkes.

His funeral will take place this evening (Friday,) at half-past 3 o'clock, from his father's residence, corner of 27th and M. streets.
The friends and acquaintances of the family are invited to attend without further notice.

div4.head: Obituary.
div4.p: Died, in Farmville, Prince Edward county, Va., on Saturday evening, the 17th instant, Frederick Willie, only child of Frederick and Sarah F. Whiteman, aged 7 years and 8 months.

Little Willie was ever a kind and obedient child, always ready to sympathize with any one in distress and to comfort them in any way he could.
Since early childhood he had a desire to become a Christian, never used bad words and would always reprove those he heard using them.
He had been instructed that God would never take him to Heaven if he was wicked in any way. He often talked about dying, and would ask his mother if she would die when he did. About an hour before his death his mother asked him if he was afraid to died to which he answered, no. She then told him he was going to Heaven to be with God; upon which he asked her, when would she meet him in that "Happy Land" He then bade her and his father and the servants all farewell, and calmly and peacefully gave up his young and sinless spirit to his maker.

lg.l: Frail, smiling solace of an hour;
So soon our transient comforts fly,
And pleasures only bloom to die."

div3.head: An Incident of the battle of Manassas.
div3.p:
--Lt. Calvin P. Everhart, of Charleston, S. C.--Recently a member of the First Regiment South Carolina Volunteers, who was in the battle of Manassas of the 21st of July, by the absence of the other officers, led three desperate charges upon one of the enemy's batteries, and he having but one hundred and six men, after taking the battery each time, and holding them till the last moment, had to fall back and leave it again in the hands of the enemy.
His men, amounting to the number above named, were reduced to about twenty-eight men, but nine of which escaped alive, but badly wounded.
Lieut. Everhart himself was also badly wounded in its foot and above the knee; though; not halting the least from his painful wounds, stepped rapidly not to a company of Virginians, and the intrepid veteran said to the Captain, "Let your men follow me; my men are all killed or wounded, and I have two brothers laying at you battery helpless and I am going to possess that battery and my brother's bodies, if God spares my life" The patriots Captain said, "I am your obedient servant, sir, lead my men to the spot" He then ordered the men to cease firing which was promptly obeys, then ordering them to dress their files, then springing forward, calling out at the top of his voice "Double quick charge;" which was immediately obeyed — his men charging with a loud shout Driving the enemy from his position, the Lieutenant sprang to the largest place of artillery, saying "This is my pride," and said, "There, Captain, it the dead bodies of my two brothers, who fought like demons till they fell."

This Lieutenant fought on till be received bullet in his left side.
He then sat down and said "Thank God, I have done a good day's work."
div3.closer:
John A Saunders,
my 23--1t* A Spectator.

div3.head:
Headquarters 11th Reg't Va. Vols,
Camp near Richmond, may 20, 1862.
div3.p: At a meeting of the Valley Regulators on this day; on motion of John K. Walter, Capt. A. M. Houston was called upon to preside and Serg't E. T. Dix to act as secretary, when the following preamble and resolutions were submitted and unanimously adopted:

Whereas, it has pleased an All-wise Providence to remove from us our brother in arms, James W. Martin, who was killed in the fight at Williamsburg, on the 6th inst., a faithful officer and a patriotic citizen:

list.item: 1st. Resolved, That while we humbly submitted this act of Divine Providence, we deeply lament his untimely death, and feel that the company has lost a good member and the army a brave soldier.
2d. Resolved, The we do most heartily sympathize with his observed wife and friends.
3d. Resolved, That a copy of the proceedings of this meeting be sent to his family, and a copy to the "Daily Dispatch" and "Lexington Gazette," and also catered on the record book of the company.

div3.closer:
A. M. Houston, or.
Edward T, Dir, Sec'y. my 23--1t

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 123, page 3.

div3.head: The War News.
div3.p: There are few persons who have a proper appreciation of the difficulties which attend an accurate compilation of the news of the day. We desire to publish none but reliable information, but in gathering this we have the same difficulties to accounter that others have to discriminate between, that which is well-founded, and that which is only seemingly correct.

Yesterday was prolific of rumors, some of which have at least the merit of probability.
The most important of these was one which obtained currency late in the afternoon, to the effect that dispatches had been received at the War Department, stating that a general fight had commenced in the morning in the vicinity of Corinth.
We visited the Department twice, to learn the correctness of the statement and the particulars of the engagement, but were unable to ascertain anything leading to a confirmation of the report.
The news under our telegraphic head, and an article published elsewhere, will furnish all the intelligence we have from the army of the Southwest.

Nearer home and around our own city matters are beginning to indicate something durative, and we may expect are long to be saluted with the hoarse mutterings of the dogs of war. From what we are able to learn of his operations, the enemy seems to be slowly and steadily approaching, and it is by no means unlikely that a grand conflict is about to commence within night of the antres of the Southern Capital.

A son of Dr. Lumpkin, of Henrico, who arrived in the city yesterday afternoon, states that the enemy in small force, made their appearance near his father's residence on Wednesday afternoon, but were driven back after a slight and indecisive skirmish.
This is about six miles-miles from the city.
Again, yesterday morning, they approached the same locality, but a few well-directed shots from a battery that had been arranged to greet their approach, caused them to quickly disperse.

Passengers by the Petersburg train yesterday afternoon report that Suffolk has been occupied by the enemy, and that the train of cars from Petersburg to that point has discontinued its regular trips to Zuni, a point on the railroad some forty miles below Petersburg.
We see nothing in this occupation of Suffolk that has not been anticipated since the evacuation of Norfolk by our forces.
We, of course, know not what is the intention of the Government with respect to Petersburg, but since its public annunciation of a determination never to surrender Richmond, the impression has prevailed that at least an effort would be made to protect our lines of communication with the South, which would seem necessary for the maintenance of the large force which is now concentrated on the north side of the James.
All conjecture is at fault, however, with reference to the military operations of our Government, and even after the consummation of its masterly manœuvres it requires no little capacity to understand or appreciate their necessity.

We have various reports from the Valley, some of which we know to be reliable, but it will not be expected of us to state where Jackson is, or what he is doing, or whether he and Ewell have formed a junction.
The account which we have satisfy us that Banks has either to evacuate that section or meet once more in deadly combat the men whose homes have been plundered by the rabble which he commands.
These men will fight desperately under the recollection of the wrongs they have sustained and the gross indignities that some of their families have been offered.

The Federals are not making much headway in subjugating the towns on the Mississippi river.
Vicksburg and Natchex utter defiance to the gunboats, whose dreaded power caused the surrender of New Orleans.
A few of the most during of their crews ventured ashore a few miles below Vicksburg, on the afternoon of the 19th, and were welcomed by bloody hands to hospitable graves.
Their attempts to get down the river are even less successful, Fort Pillow and Jeff. Thompson presenting insuperable barriers to their progress.--Any other nation than the indefatigable Yankees would have long since abandoned this was as a perfectly hopeless undertaking.

div3.head: The News from Corinth.
div3.p:
Our latest information from the command of Gen. Beauregard is up to the 21st, at which time there was heavy skirmishing, but with so definite result.
The telegram states that the indications portend a battle near at hand, and expresses the belief that the conflict may begin at any moment.
That active operations must soon commence, we have no doubt, for it is scarcely probable that the two armies, can maintain their present position much longer without a collision.

The infamous proclamation of the notorious Butter, which places the ladies of New Orleans at the mercy of his brutal soldiery, is said to have fired our army, and a feeling skin to desperation exists to drive back the minions of a Government that will tolerate such a representative.
When a fight does occur in the South, but little favor will be shown the invaders, and they will be met by men who feel that there is hardly a shade of difference between death itself and the ignominious life that would follow the success of the Federal forces in the impending conflict.
Nothing inflames a man sooner than the invasion of the sanctity of his own home, and this threat of Butler's will so fire the Southern heart that in every future engagement the soldiers of the North will be met by men who will cherish a keen recollection of a threat which has no precedent in the history of modern civilization.

The Rev. Dr. Palmer, of New Orleans, one of the most eminent divines of the whole South, recently delivered an address to the army at Corinth on this subject, which is said to have stirred them deeply.

div3.head: From Cumberland Gap.
div3.p:
A subscriber at Cumberland Gap, Tenn., sends us an account of an engagement at that point, which we had heretofore noticed.
Her writes under date of the 15th instant, and says:

q.p:
"We had a vigorous musket fight here on the 27th--distance three hundred and fifty yards. The fight lasted three hours. Our men were entrenched — the enemy were behind trees and logs.
Our loss in the engagement was three wounded--their's must have been greater.
Last night they tried to take us by surprise, when from fifty to one hundred shots were fired.
We sustained no loss.
We can whip them here, at any time, four to one."

div3.head: Election in Chesterfield.
div3.p: An election was yesterday held in the county of Chesterfield for a member of the House of Delegates to supply a vacancy created by the resignation of Charles T. Friend, Esq. We have received no returns except from the Manchester precinct, where the polls stood: Ambers 159 Gates, 11; Tatum, 2.

div3.head: Arizona.
div3.p:
--Gov. Baylor, when in Vicksburg, on his way to Richmond, spoke very favorably of affairs in the Territory of Arizona.
He is confident of being able to hold it. Fort Craig, he thinks, has ere this fallen into our hands, and General Sibley will soon have Fort Union.
He says between six and seven thousand Mexican troops, who had espoused the Federal cause, have abandoned its and are now with us. He speaks very highly of the country, and says it is the most valuable in the Confederacy.

The military authorities of Charleston have very properly stopped the further sale of the small stock of ice still remaining in that city, deeming it right to reserve it for the sick and wounded soldiers.
It is said that Lincoln will appoint Wm. G. Brownlow a Brigadier General, to lead a portion of the Federal army to Knoxville!

div3.head: From Corinth.
div3.p: --A dispatch dated Corinth, yesterday, says:

q.p:
Skirmishing continued yesterday without important results.
Our forces shelled the enemy out on the Farmington road.
No casualties on our side.
The loss of the enemy is unknown.

The indications portend a battle near at hand.
Indeed, the conflict may being at any moment.
A heavy rain this morning postponed movements.

Butler's infamous order has fired our army.
Rev. Dr. Palmer delivered an address to our troops, which stirred them deeply.
A Federal spy will be shot to-day.

div4.head: [Second Dispatch]
div4.p: --A special dispatch to the Advertiser, from Corinth, last night, says:

q.p:
There was general picket skirmishing on our right and left lines.
On the left, the enemy threw a number of shells without damage.
On our right, several casualties occurred.
Among the killed is Capt. Richards, of the 31st Mississippi.
The enemy suffered much.
A general engagement is expected to-morrow.
Our whole army marched out this evening.
Our troops are in high spirits and confident of victory.
The weather is fine and pleasant.

div4.p:
General Halleck sent two hundred Confederate prisoners having the small-pox to Fort Pillow, in exchange for Federal prisoners sent from here.
General Villepelgue refused to receive them.

General Beauregard sent a letter to Halleck to-day, charging him with bad faith and inhumanity.
Halleck replied, denying knowledge of the fact that the man had the small-pox.

div3.head: From Vicksburg.
div3.p: --The Vicksburg Whig, of the 18th, says that the enemy's gunboats were at Natchez the day previous — that city still refusing to surrender.

A dispatch to the Mobile Register, from Vicksburg, dated the 19th, says eight or ten Federal landed near Warrenton, ten miles below Vicksburg this afternoon, where they were attacked by Southerners, and four of them killed.
The rest escaped.
Our lose was one wounded. The Federal fleet is still at anchor below the city.

div3.head: From Pass Manchao.
div3.p:
--The Mobile Register has a dispatch from Pass Manchaca, dated the 18th instant, which says the Federal gunboat Creole attacked us about twelve and a half o'clock to-day.
The engagement lasted one hour and a half, when the Creole withdrew, somewhat disabled.

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p:
--Left my premises on the 12th inst, my man William, (calling himself Plummer.) Said man is a dark ginger-cake color, about 5 feet high, 25 years old, no beard; no scar remembered; had on a light suit of clothes, black oil-cloth cap, trimmed with red flannel; was raised in the city of Richmond, and left my house with the intention of going to Richmond, by way of Richmond and Danville railroad.
William is a good brick and rock mason.
Wm. S. Moseley.
Address: Red Oak Grove, Charlotte co., Va. my 28--3t

div3.head:
Headquarter Valley District,
Mount ,may 17, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No, 47.

Brig, Gen. Geo. H. Stewart having reported for duty will, in obedience to special order No. 107, Adjutant and Inspector General's office, Richmond, May 9th, 1861, proceed to organize the Maryland Line, and for this purpose the First Maryland regiment is detached from its present brigade organization, and placed under his command.

I would strongly urge every patriotic Marylander who has oust his destiny with the Southern Confederacy to come promptly forward and join this organization, headed by one of Maryland's gifted sons, and to do what he can to make the Maryland Line invincible against the tyranny which continues to trample in the dust the rights of his native State.
div3.closer:
(Signed) T. J. Jackson,
my 28--1t Major General.

div3.head:
Henrico Artillery.
Ritter's Battery.
div3.p: A men absent from this company without leave are hereby ordered to report themselves forthwith for duty, at the camp at Fairfield Race Course, or they will be advertised and treated as deserters.
The following parties are deserters — for whose apprehension and delivery to any officer a liberal reward will be paid:

list.item: Peter Brennan,
Jas. De Courcey,
Anthony Doherty,
Patrick Doherty,
Thos. Gleason,
John Grady,
Jas. A. Harvey,
Martin Harvey,
Alex'r Henderson,
Timothy Sullivan,
John R. Woodward,
Patrick Hartnett,
Jerry Lynne,
Roger Meghan,
Patrick Maloney,
Barnard McDearmon,
Daniel Murphy,
Simon O'Neill,
Michael Sullivan,
Thos. Welsh.

div3.p: Meghan and Maloney took away horses belonging to the battery.
div3.closer:
W. B. Ritter, Captain.
my 23--8t Com'g Company.

div3.head:
Attention!
Marylanders.
div3.p: The undersigned is authorized by the Secretary of War to enlist a Partisan Company of Marylanders, to be attached to the Maryland Line, under the orders of Brigadier-General Stenart; to be enlisted for the war, and to receive the same bounty, ($50,) pay, &c., as other volunteers.
Horses will be furnished by private contribution to those who are unable to procure them, and the Government will furnish arms and equipments where needed.

Native or adopted citizens of Maryland now in the service, in any regiment other than the 1st Maryland regiment, who wish to join this arm of service can be transferred under General Order No. 8, Special Order No. 107, by application to Major Geo H. Kyle, or to
div3.closer:
G. M. Emack,
Lt. C. S. A. and Recruiting Officer,
my 28--1w No. 14 Pearl st., Richmond.

div3.head: Partisan Troop for Kentucky and Tennessee!.
div3.p:
--I am authorized to raise a Partisan Troop for operations in Kentucky and Tennessee.
Those who wish to join in this "dashing," "dare-devil" business, and serve their country like good and true men, can do so by applying to me.--There will be $50 bounty granted by the Government, and the troop will be well mounted and thoroughly equipped!
None but sound, good, dashing fellows need apply; for, as the service will be chivalrous, adventurous, and dangerous, none but unexceptionable young men will be received., Those who wish to emulate Morgan and his troop have now an opportunity by applying to
div3.closer:
Capt. Wm. H. Rowan,
No. 12, Columbian Hotel, 18th street.
my 23--ts

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
In consequence of not being able to purchase horses in Richmond, I have deemed it best to make Lynchburg the point of rendezvous for my company of Partisan Rangers Additional members will be received.
The attention of those desiring to join my company is called to the fact that they will be furnished with horses and equipments, and the usual bounty of $50 will be paid.
My office, on Bank, near 10th street, will be kept open, where transportation to place of rendezvous can be had. I am anxious to go into service at an early day; hence, those who feel disposed to join my company will please report at once.
div3.closer: my 23--8t L. R. Smoot.

div3.head:
Hd'qrs Mounted Riflemen,
Scott's Partisan Rangers,
Opp.
Spotswood Hotel.
div3.p:
Every member of this company is ordered to report to me, at the Recruiting Office, by 9 o'clock, at which time he will be mustered in with the company, draw his bounty, and receive his commutation for clothing.
Every one who his signed the muster-roll failing to report will be reported to the Provost Marshal, and arrested wherever found.
div3.closer:
Edw'd McCONNELL. Jr.
Capt. Mounted Riflemen,
my 23--2t and Recruiting Officer.

div3.head:
General Hospital.
Richmond,may 28, 1862.
div3.p:
all patients registered in this Hospital, who have been permitted to reside outside the building, will report to me in person at this Hospital at 2.
P. M. on Saturday, 24th instant.

If too unwell to report in person, they will report through some regular practitioner of medicine; military or civil.
Failing to do so, they will be advertised as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of Surgeon General. Ch. Bell Gibson,
Surgeon P. A. C. S.
my 23--1t In charge of Gen'l Hosp'l.

div3.head:
Royster Hospital.
Richmond, Va.,may 28, 1862.
div3.p: all out-patients of this hospital will report themselves at this hospital, either personally or through a regular practitioner of medicine, either military or civil, within twenty-four hours.
Failing to comply with this order, they will be advertised as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of the Surgeon General. O. A. Crenshaw.
my 23--1t Surgeon in charge hospital.

div3.head:
Second Georgia Hospital,
Richmond,may 22, 1862.
div3.p: out-patients of this hospital are required "to report within 24 hours, either in person or through some regular practitioner of medicine, military or civil Failing to do which they will be advertised as deserters."
div3.closer:
J. A. S. Milligan,
my 28--1t Acting Surgeon in charge.

div3.head:
Confederate Blues,
attention!
div3.p:
You will meet this evening at military Hall, at 8¼ o'clock.
Every member is requested to be present.
Sergeants will notify their respective squads.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. R. H. Duesber A Y.
W. B. Davis, O. S. my28 — 1t

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--All soldiers in private quarters, from Greanor's Hospital, are ordered to report to me within 24 hours either in person or through some regular practitioner of medicine, military or civil.
Falling to do so, they will be advertised as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of Surg. Gen. Moore, C. S. A.,
Samuel B. Fisher, Surg in charge of
my 28--1t Greanor's Hospital.

div3.head: An act to organize a home Guard--[passed may 14, 1862:

list.item:
1.Be it enacted, by the General Assembly, That the citizens of each of the counties of this Commonwealth who are not subject to, and those who are exempt from, military duty by the laws of this State or of the Confederate States, be, and the same are hereby, authorized to raise, by voluntary enlistment, one or more companies of not less than fifty nor more than one hundred men, rank and file, to act as a home guard for said counties; and whenever a sufficient number shall be raised to form a company, they are hereby authorized, under the superintendence of a commissioned officer of the county, or of such person as the Governor may designate, to elect a Captain and two Lieutenants, whose election shall be certified by the officer or person conducting the same, to the Governor of this Commonwealth, who shall thereupon commission said officers.
The Captain of each company is hereby authorized to appoint therefore four sergeants and four corporals.

2.The said companies are hereby authorized to adopt such by laws and regulations for their government as they may choose, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State or of the Confederate States.
Said force, when in actual service, shall be governed by, and be subject to, all rules, regulations and articles of war which may be in force at the time for the government of the troops of the Confederate States.

3.
The said companies shall operate as a guard and police for their respective counties during the war; and their officer in command is hereby authorized to order such force to rendezvous at any point that he may determine upon, whenever in his opinion the safety of the county may require at. Whenever two or more companies shall be organized in a county, they may elect a Major, who shall be commissioned by the Governor to command the whole: Provided, however, that the troops hereby authorized to be raised shall not be marched beyond the limits of their respective counties against their consent, or kept in active service for more than thirty days at any one time.

4. The troops hereby authorized to be raised shall furnish their own weapons, and shall not be entitled to compensation for their services, except that they shall be furnished with the rations authorized by law when in actual service; but the Governor shall provide them with such ammunition as the exigency of the service may require, to be deposited with the senior officer of said corps in each county, who shall give bond and security for the proper disposition of the same.

5.The officer in command shall have power, when in active service, to appoint a quartermaster, who shall act as commissary, and who shall give bond and security for the faithful performance of his duty in such penalty as the officer aforesaid shall require.
6.This act shall be in force from its passage.

div3.p: A copy from the rolls — Teste:
div3.closer:
Wm. F. Gordon, Jr.
C. H. D. and K. of E.
By Jno. T. Cowan, Deputy. my 21--2t

div3.head: Ten thousand Virginia troops to be commanded by General Floyd.
div3.p: an act to authorize a force of ten thousand men to be raised for the defence of the Commonwealth--[Passed May 17, 1862.

list.item: 1.Be it enacted, by the General Assembly, That the Governor of this Commonwealth be, and he is hereby, authorized to commission John B. Floyd a Major General of the State of Virginia, with authority to raise by voluntary enlistment a force not exceeding ten thousand men, who are not now in the service of the State of Virginia or of the Confederate States, or liable to draft under the act of Congress commonly called the "Conscription law," approved the 16th day of April, 1862: Provided, That the Governor shall have authority to appoint to the offices hereinafter authorized to be filled by him any persons in the Confederate service, or liable thereto under the Conscription law aforesaid, whom the President of the Confederate States may content to discharge from the Confederate service.

2. That the said force shall be divided into two brigades, to be composed of five regiments, of not less than one thousand men each; for which brigades the Governor is authorized to appoint and commission two Brigadier-Generals; and such appointment may be made for either brigade, when three regiments in such brigade shall have been raised, organized, and officered.

3. The Governor shall appoint and commission forthwith ten captains for each regiment in each brigade, with authority to raise, by opening recruiting stations or otherwise, companies of one hundred men each, including commissioned, non-commissioned officers and privates; and whenever ten companies are raised and mustered into service as required by law, the Governor shall cause the same to be organized into a regiment, and shall appoint and commission therefore one colonel, one lieutenant-colonel, and one major, to command the same.
Each of the said companies shall be, and is hereby, authorized to elect one first and two second lieutenants; the said elections to be superintended by the captains, and to be certified to the Governor and commissioned by him. The captain of each of said companies is authorized to appoint therefore five sergeants and four corporals.

4. That all vacancies shall be filled by the Governor from the company, battalion, squadron, or regiment in which such vacancies shall occur, by promotion according to seniority, except in cases of disability or other incompetency, and whenever a vacancy shall occur in the lowest grade of commissioned officers of a company said vacancy shall be filled by election as herein before provided.
5. In each brigade the Governor is hereby authorized to appoint and commission as many captains of cavalry, and as many captains of artillery as he, in his discretion, may think proper.

6. The staff of the major-general shall consist of two aide-de-camp, one assistant adjutant general, one division quartermaster, who shall act as commissary, each with the rank of like officers in the service of the Confederate States: Provided, however, That the division quartermaster shall not be appointed unless two brigades, of not less than three regiments each, have been raised.

7. The staff of each brigadier general shall consist of one aide-de-camp, one assistant adjutant general, and one quartermaster, who shall act as commissary, each with the rank and pay of first lieutenant of cavalry.

8. The staff of a colonel shall consist of one quartermaster, who shall act as commissary, one surgeon, two assistant surgeons, one adjutant, with the rank of similar officers in the Confederate service, one sergeant-major, one quarter master's sergeant, and two musicians.

9.The Governor shall cause the said division hereby authorized to be raised to be armed and equipped according to the description of the force, whether artillery, cavalry, riflemen, or infantry, with the best description of arms and ordnance possible to be procured, and to furnish them with the necessary equipments, ammunition and munitions of war, with suitable camp equipage and transportation.
The cavalry, however, shall furnish their own horses, on the same terms as in the Confederate service.

10. The said force, as soon as they are mustered into service, which shall be for the term of twelve months, shall be governed by the articles of war, which may be in force at the time for the government of the troops of the Confederate States, and shall be subject to the orders of the Governor of Virginia for such duty as he may require, not inconsistent with the Constitution and laws of this State, or of the Confederate State.
The officers and privates of the forces herein authorized to be raised, shall receive the same pay, allowance and rations as officers and privates of the same grade and in like service are entitled to in the service of the Confederate States, except that they shall receive no county; and no officer authorized to be commissioned by this act, nor non-commissioned officer or private, shall receive pay before being mustered into the service of the State, subject to the orders of the Governor.

11. To carry into effect the provisions of this act the sum of two millions five hundred thousand dollars shall be, and the same is hereby, appropriated out of any money in the Treasury not otherwise appropriated; and the Governor and Auditor of Public Accounts are authorized, if necessary, to borrow from time to time, at a raise of interest not exceeding six per centum, parts of said sum of money, or to cause registered stock of the Commonwealth to be issued and sold at part for the purpose of raising from time to time parts of said sum of money; or, if the necessary amount of money should not be so obtained, to cause to be issued Treasury notes of the Commonwealth, in the manner as provided for in the ordinance of the Convention authorizing the issue of Treasury notes, but without interest.

12. The Governor may authorize such portion of the said ten thousand men as he may deem proper to be raised for service in particular sections of the State, or for co-operation with particular departments of the Confederate army, so long as they may be needed in such district, and for this purpose may confer special authority on such number of officers as he may deem expedient, who, when the requisite number are raised, shall be commissioned by him; but the troops thus raised by him shall at all times be subject to the orders of the Governor, and may, whenever in his opinion it is proper, be ordered for service to any portion of the Commonwealth.

div3.p: In enacting the foregoing bill the General Assembly does not, to any extent whatever intend to censure the recent action of the Confederate Executive in reference to General John B Floyd, or to express, by implication or otherwise, any opinion on that subject.
This act shall be in force from its passage.
A copy from the rolls — Teste:
div3.closer:
William F. Gordon, Jr.,
C. H. D. and K. of R.
By John T. Cowan, Deputy. my21 — 2t

div3.head: An act to Amend and re-en act section 8 chapter 205 of the Code of Virginia.--[passed may 9. 1862.
div3.p: Be it enacted by the General Assembly, That section 5 of chapter 205 of the Code of Virginia be a banded and re-enacted, so as to read as follows:

p.q: "The Court at any such special session may adjourn the examination to the next regular term, quarterly or monthly, or at an earlier day, and at a regular term may continue an examination from term to term, so that such continuance, except on the motion of the accused, or in time of war, or by reason of the witness for the Commonwealth being enticed or kept away, or prevented from attending, or by sickness or some inevitable accident shall not be beyond the third-regular term after the examination was ordered; but if an examination be commenced at any term, such term may be extended until the examination is concluded."

div3.p: This act shall be in force from its passage.
A copy from the rolls — Tests:
div3.closer:
Wm. F. Gordon, Jr.,
C. H. D. and K. of R.
By Jno. T. Cowan, Deputy. my 21--2t

div3.head: An act to Amend and re-enact section of chapter 207 of the Code of Virginia.--[passed may 9. 1862.
div3.p: Be it enacted, by the General Assembly, That section thirteen of chapter two hundred and seven of the Code of Virginia, be amended and re-enacted so as to read as follows:

p.q: "Except in time of war, a person in jail on a criminal charge shall be discharge from imprisonment, if he be not indicted before the end of the second term of the Court at which he is held to answer, unless it appear to the Court that material, witnesses for the Commonwealth have been enticed or kept away, or are prevented from attendance by sickness or inevitable accident, and except, also, in the case provided in the following section."

div3.p: This act shall be in force from its passage.
A copy from the rolls — Tests:

closer.signed: C. H. D. and K. of E.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 123, page 4.

div3.head: A modern Castle of Adolpho,
div3.p: A correspondent sends the following remarkable story to the Dublin Evening Mail:

This is the age of discoveries, and one of such a startling nature has just been made in an English county that it seems out of place in the region of sober fact, and to belong purely to the atmosphere of the three volume novel.
Mere are the circumstances, the names for the moment I am not at liberty to indicate: The Earl of — married not long ago, and brought his bride home to one of the old family mansions which members of the English aristocracy regard with an affection amounting to veneration.
The lady, however, being more continental in her tastes, after a short residence in the apartments appropriated to her use, expressed a wish to have a boudoir in the vicinity of her bed-room.

The noble Earl would gladly have complied with the request, but, upon examination, it was found that the rooms, as sometimes happens in antique buildings, were so awkwardly distributed that by no conceivable plan of re-arrangement could the desired boudoir be fitted in. Thereupon it became necessary to invoke professional assistance, and an eminent architect was summoned from London.
He examined the house narrowly, and said there seemed to be nothing for it but to build one, though at the same time he could not resist the impression that there must be another undiscovered room somewhere in that wing of the mansion.
The noble Earl laughed at the idea; the oldest servants and retainers of the family were questioned, and declared that they had never heard even a rumor of its existence.
The ordinary methods of tapping, &c., were resorted to, but without effect.
Still the architect retained his conviction, and declared himself ready to stake his professional reputation on the result.

The Earl at last consented to let the walls be bored, and, when an opening had been made, not only was the room found, but a night presented itself which almost defeats attempts at description.
The apartment was fitted up in the richest and most luxurious style of 150 years ago. A quantity of ladies' apparel lay about the room, jewels were scattered on the dressing table, and, but for the faded aspect which everything wore, the chamber might have been tenanted half an hour previously.
On approaching the bed the most curious sight of all was seen, and this is which affords the only clue to the mystery.
The couch held the skeleton of a woman, and on the floor, underneath the bed, half in and half out, lay another skeleton, that of a man, presenting evident traces of violence, and proving that, before he expired in that position, he must have received some dreadful injury.
The secret connected with this tale of blood has been well kept, for not merely had all tradition of the scene faded away, but even the existence of the room itself was forgotten.
The survivors probably walled up the apartment at the time, and its contents remained hermetically sealed up till the present day, when, according to the best calculations, after the lapse of a century and a half, daylight has accidentally penetrated into this chamber of horrors.

div3.head: Home duty.
div3.p:
--The undersigned, by authority of the Secretary of War, is raising a company for Garrison, Guard, and Prison duty.
All good men, between 35 and 45 years, persons not already in the service, and those who have been discharged, will be received.
The usual clothing and bounty money given, with subsistence until the company is organized.
Apply at Gen. Winder's office.
div3.closer:
Warner Lewis,
A. D. C. to Brig., Gen. John H. Winder.
my 22--3t*

div3.head: Maryland Line.
div3.p:
--I am authorized to raise an Infantry Company for the Maryland Line.
Citizens of Maryland desiring to united themselves with the line, are invited to join me.--The company with elect its own officers.
I can be found for the present at the Pay Office of the Confederate Forces, corner of Bank and 10th streets. Bounty and transportation furnished without delay.
div3.closer:
Campbell Pinckney,
my 22--t81stM* Of Maryland.

div3.head: Deserted
div3.p: --From my company, at Camp Winder, the following men, for which I will pay the reward of thirty dollars each, if delivered at the Provost Marshal's office:

Julius Lang, aged 20 years, gray eyes, dark hair, dark complexion, about 5 feet 71 inches high.
Born in Hessen, Germany, and by profession a shoemaker.

Julius T. Polk, aged 29 years, brown eyes, auburn hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 11 inches high.
Born in Southampton, Virginia, and by profession a printer; he is well known in this city.

Frederick Brune, aged 30 years, brown eyes, auburn hair, light complexion, 5 feet 8 inches high.
Born in Wirtenberg, Germany.
and by profession a ship carpenter.
It is supposed that he has enlisted in some cavalry company near the city.

John Smith, aged 23 years, gray eyes, auburn hair, dark complexion, 5 feet 8 inches high.
Born in Liverpool, England, and by profession a laborer; has lost his left eye.
All members in the city and absent without leave will immediately report at camp, or be advertised as deserters.
div3.closer:
John Herbig,
Captain of Infirmary Company.
Camp Winder, May 20, 1862. my 21--4t*

div3.head: Partisan Rangers.
div3.p:
--Authorized by the Secretary of War.
According to the recent act of Congress, creating a "Partisan Corps," to muster into service a squadron of two or more companies of Mounted hangers for immediate action, I still upon my friends from the country lying between the "Blue Ridges" and the "Occoquan," to unite with me in this favored corps; as by previous experience as a Cavalry officer, engaged for twelve months in similar service with a knowledge of the field of operations.
I believe we may contribute much to the benefit of our cause.

Communications may be addressed me at Gordonsville, Orange county.
Va. Recruits will be provided for at that Station.
div3.closer:
Bounty, $50. Pay, &c., as Cavalry. Ed. B. Powell,
Late Captain Co. F. 6th Va. Cavalry.
my 21--6t*

div3.head:
Headquarters Co F, 23d Va. Vols
army of the Valley.
div3.p:
Deserters.--Private John T. Warrener, of company F, after receiving his bounty and furlough, has never returned.
Said Warrener is about 21 years of age; medium size; red, bluffly face; curly hair, and altogether has a bad countenance.
Up to the time of re-enlistment, he had been of very little service to his company He is supposed to be lurking in the neighborhood of Rocketts.

On the 5th of May, private S. P. Johnson, aged 38 years. He, by his previous course of conduct, seems entirely indisposed to serve his country.
Whatever is due the above-named men will be paid for their delivery at camp.
Other members of this corps absent on sick furloughs, will report immediately at headquarters.--If unable by sickness, they will send a Surgeon's certificate to that effect.
div3.closer: my 20--14t* T. S. Michaels, Captain.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All members of the Allen Artillery absent with or without leave, will report immediately at Battery No. 3, or they will be published as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of T. P. Wilkinson, Captain Commanding Allen Artillery.
my 20--6t* Geo W. Boss, O. S.

div3.head: Special notice.
div3.p:
--Persons belonging to the 8th and 14th Alabama, and the 14th Louisiana regiments--Pryor's Brigade — will report at once to their respective Regimental Headquarters.
Otherwise they will be published and prosecuted as deserters.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig., Gen. Pryor:
my 19--7t* Jno. E. Jones, A. D. C.

div3.head: Maryland Partisan corps.
div3.p: --It is proposed to organized a Partisan corps of Maryland men, to act as nearly as possible on the frontier of our own State.
The corps to consist of Cavalry, Artillery and Infantry, and to be under command of Colonel Walter H. Jenifer, who has accepted the same.
Horses will be furnished to those who desire to join the cavalry, if unable to provide their own.

The Secretary of War having decided that Marylanders are exempt from the provisions of the Conscription act, all twelve months men from that State can claim transfer to this corps at or after the expiration of their term of service.
Pay, rations and bounty same as in regular service.
div3.closer:
J. A. Weston,
my 10--ts 15 Pearl street.

div3.head: Maryland Partisan corps.
div3.p: The attention of Maryland and District men is called to this service, to which they are so particularly adapted, and which will give them the best opportunity to avenge the insults offered to our glorious old State.
Already three entire companies of the 1st Maryland regiment have joined, and a majority from several of the other companies have requested to be transferred.
This corps will be independent of all other commands, save that of the General commanding the Department of Virginia, and will act as nearly as possible on the frontiers of Maryland.

As the Conscription act does not apply to Marylanders, they occupy the same position as though it had never been passed, and hence all 12 months men can claim transfer to this corps, if re-enlisted; or, if not re-enlisted, can be discharged upon or after the expiration of their term of service.
Horses will be furnished those who desire to join the Cavalry and are unable to provide their own.
In addition to the pay, rations, and bounty, (which are the same as in regular service,) the value of all captures from the enemy will be distributed among the men.
The corps will be composed of Cavalry, Artillery, and Infantry, and commanded by a distinguished officer of the army.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining the command will apply to
div3.closer:
J. A. Weston,
my 14--ts 15 Pearl street.

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive Substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.
div3.closer:
A. B. Guigon,
mh 28-- Captain Light Artillery.

div3.head:
War Department,
Adjutant General office,
Richmond, Va., may 17, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No. 36.

list.item: I. All applications for discharge, made by persons over 85 years of age, who may have been drafted since 10th March, 1862. under the Virginia laws, and assigned to military organizations serving under authority of the Confederate States, will be granted by Brigade commanders; regimental and company commanders causing to be made out and signing the "Soldier's Discharge" and "Final Statements" required in all cases of discharge, said papers to indicate cause for the discharge.

II.
In all cases where promotion is due from seniority and the competency of the parties entitled by position to promotion is questionable, a Board of Examiners shall be convened by Brigade Commanders to determine the candidates' capabilities of instructing and controlling the commands commensurate with grade to which promotion is expected, as also their efficiency and perfect sobriety.

div3.closer:
By order of the Secretary of War. (Signed) S. Cooper,
my 19--1w Adj't and Inspector General

div3.head: Partisan Rangers.--
div3.p:
My Battalion of Mounted Rangers will be ready to take the field in two weeks. Only one more company required.
Those wishing to unite will please address me immediately.
div3.closer:
Lt.-Col. W. C. Claiborne,
my 10--ts Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Persons wishing to join the Secret service for the war, will have the privilege of doing so by calling at my office, over the counting room of Messrs. McKinney & Dupuy, Shockoe Slip, near Columbian Hotel.
Office will be open from the 12th inst.
div3.closer:
B. F. Bowles,
my 9--12t* Captain.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --The Capital Stock of the "Piedmont Railroad Company" having been all taken by the Richmond and Danville Railroad company and others, it is desired by them and the Government of the Confederate States that the work of construction should be commenced and completed as speedily as possible.

Some delay being otherwise necessary for the new company to be organized, in the meantime notice is hereby given to all persons having hands to hire, that employment may be obtained for such hands on the line of the said railroad, as soon as the Piedmont Railroad Company is organized, which is expected to be in about thirty or forty days from this time; and all such persons are requested to communicate speedily with the President of the Richmond and Danville Railroad Company, or with Vincent Witcher and John R. Edmunds, of the Directors, who are authorized to make provisional agreements for the employment of such hands for that purpose.
div3.closer:
Lewis E Harvie,
my 10--20t President R. and D. R. R. Ca.

div3.head: Chewing Tobacco.
div3.p: --The finest and most popular brands of Chewing and Smoking Tobacco for sale by
div3.closer:
W. Peterson & Co.,
ap 12 Druggists, 165 Main st.

div3.head: Exemption.
div3.p: The following General Order is published by authority of the Secretary of War:

div4.head:
War Department,
Adj't and Insp's Gen's office,
Richmond, may 19, 1862.
div4.p: General Orders, No. 37.

list.item:
I. The following act and regulations in reference thereto, are published for the information of all concerns:
an act to exempt certain persons from enrollment for service in the armies of the Confederate States.
Section1. The Congress of the Confederate States of America do enact, That all person who shall be held to be unfit for military service under rules to be prescribed by the Secretary of War--all in the service or employ of the Confederate States--all judicial and executive officers of the Confederate or State Governments — the members of both Houses of Congress and the Legislatures of the several States and their respective officers — all clerks of the officers of the State and Confederate Governments allowed by law — all engaged in carrying the mails — all ferrymen on post routes — all pilots and persons engaged in the marine service on river and railroad routes of transportation — telegraphic operators and ministers of religion in the regular discharge of ministerial duties — all engaged in working Iron mines, furnaces, and foundries — all journeymen printers actually employed in printing newspapers — all presidents and professors of colleges and academies, and all teachers having as many as twenty scholars — superintendents of the public hospitals, lunatic asylums, and the regular nurses and attendants therein, and the teachers employed an the institutions for the deaf and blind — in each apothecary store now established and doing business, one apothecary in good standing, who is a practical druggist — superintendents and operatives in wool and cotton factories who may be exempted by the Secretary of War, shall be, and are hereby, exempted from military service in the armies of the Confederate States.
Approved April 21, 1862.

II.
By the above act of Congress, the following classes of persons are exempt from enrollment for military service:
Justices of the Peace; Sheriffs and Deputy Sheriffs; Clerks and Deputy Clerks, allowed by law; Masters and Commissioners in Chancery; District and State Attorneys; Attorney General; Postmasters and Deputy Postmasters, and Clerks allowed by law; Commissioners of Revenue, and foreigners who have not acquired domicil in the Confederate States.

III.
The following are not exempt:
Militia Officers not in actual service; persons exempt by State laws, but not by the above act; foreigners who have acquired domicil in the Confederate States.

IV.
No persons other than those expressly named or properly implied in the above act can be exempted, except by furnishing a substitute, exempt from military service, in conformity with regulations already published, (General Orders No. 29;) and such exemption is valid only so long as the said substitute is legally exempt.

V. Persons who have furnished substitutes will receive their certificates of exemption from the Captains of companies, or the Commandants of camps, by whom the substitutes have been accepted.
Other certificates of exemption will be granted by the enrolling officers only, who will receive full instructions in regard to the conditions and mode of exemptions.
Applications for exemption cannot, therefore, be considered by the War Department.

div4.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
S. Cooper,
Adj't and Insp'r Gen'l.

div4.p: the following are the regulations concerning substitutes, above referred to:

list.head: General Orders, no. 29.
list.item:
I. The following regulations concerning substitutes in the army are published by the direction of the Secretary of War:
1.
Any non-commissioned officer or soldier not indebted to the Government, who wishes to procure a substitute, may obtain from his captain a permit for the proposed substitute to report himself at the camp of the company for examination; and such permit shall operate as a passport, but shall not entitle the holder to transportation at the expense of the Government.
2. If the substitute be exempt from military duty, and, on examination by a surgeon or assistant surgeon of the army, be pronounced sound and in all respects fit for-military service, he shall be enrolled and mustered into service for three years, unless the war sooner terminate; and the non-commissioned officer or soldier procuring him shall thereupon be discharged, but shall not be entitled to transportation at the expense of the Government.
3. If a non-commissioned officer or soldier discharged by reason of a substitute be indebted to the Government, the officer granting the discharge shall be liable for the debt.
4. All pay and allowance due to the noncommissioned officer or soldier discharged shall go to the substitute at the next pay day.
5.
Substitution shall not exceed one per month in each company, and shall be noted in the next morning report, muster roll, and monthly return.

II.
When any person liable to military duty under the act of Congress, but not mustered into service in any company, desires to furnish a substitute, he shall report himself, with the substitute, to the commandant of a camp of instruction, for recruits raised under the said act; and if the substitute be lawfully exempt from military duty, and, on examination by a surgeon or assistant surgeon, be pronounced sound, and in all respects fit for military service, he may be accepted and enrolled, and the person furnishing such a substitute may be discharged by the commandant of the camp.
But no substitute shall be entitled to transportation or other allowance at the expense of the Government until so accepted and enrolled.
my 20--d1w

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico.
Richmond, may 15th, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders, No.--
I At a General Court-Martial assembled at Richmond, Va., pursuant to Paragraph II, Special Orders No. 57, Headquarters Department Henrico, April 2d, 1862. were arraigned and tried--
1st.

2d. Captain Wm. F. McLean, of Company (A) 59th Regiment Virginia volunteers, formerly known as the Ben McCulloch Rangers 2d Regiment Infantry, Wise Legion, upon the following charges and specifications!
(The specifications being so various and detailed are omitted in this order)

div4.head: Charge first.
div4.p: Exciting mutiny in a company in the service of the Confederate States, in violation of the 7th Article of War.

div4.head: Charge Second.
div4.p: Fraudulent conversion to his own use of property belonging to others, which came into his possession by virtue of his office as Captain.

div4.head: Charge third.
div4.p: Allowing members of his company to leave the service without a proper discharge.
To which charges and specifications the accused pleaded Not Guilty, and the Court having maturely considered the evidence adduced, find the said Captain William F. McLean, as follows:

p.q: "On the first specification of the first charge, Guilty, except the words, 'addressed to him as Captain of said Company;' On the second specification of first charge, Guilty; On the first specification of first charge, Not Guilty; On the fourth specification of first charge, Guilty, On the first charge, Guilty; On the first specification of second charge, Guilty; On the second specification of second charge, Not Guilty; On the third specification of second charge, Guilty; On the fourth specification of second charge, Not Guilty; On the second charge, Guilty; On the specification of third charge, Not Guilty; On the third charge, Not Guilty;"

div4.p:
And the Court therefore sentences the said Captain Wm. F. McLean "to be cashiered, and do order that his offence name, place of bode, and punishment, be published in the news papers of Richmond.
Va., and New Orleans, La"

II.
The proceedings, findings, and sentence of the Court in the foregoing case are hereby approved; and the said Captain Wm. F. McLean, of New Orleans La., ceases from this date to be an officer of the Confederate States Army.
div4.closer:
By order of
Brig., Gen. John H. Winder,
Commanding, &c.
L. R. Page, A. A. General.
my 20--6t

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay the above reward for the arrest and delivery to me of a man calling himself John Manning.
Said Manning is 26 or 30 years old, stout but straight figure, 5 feet 6 or 10-inches high, of fair skin, ruddy complexion, light eyes, dark, sandy hair, inclined to curl, and was, when he deserted, well dressed in a gray sack coat and dark pantaloons.
He had a recent paper from C. S. Court of his intention to be naturalized.
He is doubtless lurking about Richmond, endeavoring to hire himself as a substitute.
He is an Irishman.
W. T. Patton,
Lt., Col. Commanding 7th Reg. Va.,
1st Brigade, Long street's Division.

div3.head: Runaway--$50,00 reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay the above reward for the apprehension or delivery to me of my negro woman Julia.
She left my house--No. 41., Pearl street — on the 15th of May. She is about twenty five years of age, short, and thick set; on her left arm has a heart printed with India ink, and two letters not recollected; she is a dark brown, and has a rather shuffling walk, and somewhat of a downcast look when spoken to; she has a full head of hair, and generally wears it plaited.
my 21--3t* J. H. Hitchcock.

div3.head: $200 reward.
div3.p:
--On Thursday last, while I was in the War Department on business, I sent my servant, Austin, who is so well known in Richmond, to the post-office, since which time I have not seen him or been able to obtain any information of his whereabouts.
If he has been impressed I will give $20 to any person who will inform me where he is. If he has been kidnapped, I will give $100 for his recovery.
If he has run off, which I do not believe, I will give $200 for his recovery; or if he has been killed, which I fear, I will pay $200 for the conviction of his murderer.
my 20--4t* James Lyons.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--The above reward will be paid for any information that will lead to the recovery of my boy Daniel.
He is 15 years of age, of light complexion, five feet six inches high, and was last seen at Williamsburg, Va., on the 4th May. He was unwell, and may have gone with the wagons of another brigade.
Address.
J. R. Seay,
Co. C, 6th Reg't S. C. V.,
Longstreet's Division, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Left my residence on Franklin street, between 7th and 8th, on Saturday, 10th instant, my negro man Ralph.
The above reward will be paid for his arrest and delivery to me, or placed in any jail so that I can get him. He is about 5 feet 10 or 11 inches high, light mulatto, high cheek bones, and a full suit of nearly straight hair, cut closely.
my 19--12t* A. L. Ellett.

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the owner, on Second street, near Main, in this city, on Monday night, the 12th inst., a negro girl, Ann Jackson.
She is of a bright, brown color, and of about the age of 14, and 5½ feet in height.
It is believed she was enticed away by a free boy of the name of Wilson Page, and is now in or near the city.
The above reward will be paid for her arrest and return to us.
Barksdale & Bro.,
Corner Cary and 13th streets, up stairs.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, near Dayton, Marengo county, Ala., my dining-room servant, James, sometimes calling himself James Clarke, a bright mulatto, about twenty-five years of age, slightly bowlegged; was raised in Richmond, Va, by a Mr. Totty.
His parents still live there.--James was in the army last summer at Winchester.
A reasonable reward will be paid for his apprehension and confinement in jail so that I get him again.
my 10--1m* Edward Baptist.

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my store, on Tuesday morning, 15th instant, my negro Boy, Lewis Washington.
He is a bright mulatto, thickset, about 5 feet high, 15 years old; had on when last seen a brown sack coat, brown pants, and a military cap. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me.
S. S. Cottrell,
ap 2--ts No. 129 Main street.
